body: Thanks for reviewing @dusenberrymw!
All tests passed: https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/916/console

Hi @dusenberrymw. I built a SystemML.jar based on the master branch and a SystemML.jar based on this branch. I did the following:

```
1a) PYSPARK_PYTHON=python3 pyspark --driver-class-path $SYSTEMML_HOME/SystemML-master.jar test_matrix_agg_fn.py
1b) PYSPARK_PYTHON=python3 pyspark --driver-class-path $SYSTEMML_HOME/SystemML-master.jar test_matrix_binary_op.py
1c) PYSPARK_PYTHON=python3 pyspark --driver-class-path $SYSTEMML_HOME/SystemML-master.jar test_mlcontext.py
1d) PYSPARK_PYTHON=python3 pyspark --driver-class-path $SYSTEMML_HOME/SystemML-master.jar test_mllearn_df.py
1e) PYSPARK_PYTHON=python3 pyspark --driver-class-path $SYSTEMML_HOME/SystemML-master.jar test_mllearn_numpy.py

2a) PYSPARK_PYTHON=python3 pyspark --driver-class-path $SYSTEMML_HOME/SystemML-branch.jar test_matrix_agg_fn.py
2b) PYSPARK_PYTHON=python3 pyspark --driver-class-path $SYSTEMML_HOME/SystemML-branch.jar test_matrix_binary_op.py
2c) PYSPARK_PYTHON=python3 pyspark --driver-class-path $SYSTEMML_HOME/SystemML-branch.jar test_mlcontext.py
2d) PYSPARK_PYTHON=python3 pyspark --driver-class-path $SYSTEMML_HOME/SystemML-branch.jar test_mllearn_df.py
2e) PYSPARK_PYTHON=python3 pyspark --driver-class-path $SYSTEMML_HOME/SystemML-branch.jar test_mllearn_numpy.py
```

The python tests from the master branch and this branch showed identical behavior:

```
1a) 15 ran
1b) 29 ran, 3 failed
1c) 9 ran
1d) 3 ran
1e) 5 ran

2a) 15 ran
2b) 29 ran, 3 failed
2c) 9 ran
2d) 3 ran
2e) 5 ran
```
@asurve  Also, when you are back, can you please replace this with your PL_Scala2 branch to avoid confusion ?
All tests pass: https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/919/console

Please see https://github.com/niketanpansare/incubator-systemml/blob/matmult_cpp_experiments/scripts/perftest/runMatMultExperiments.sh in case if you want to reproduce the result on a different machine.

@dusenberrymw @nakul02 @fschueler As an FYI, with some preliminary experiments, Java is outperforming OpenBLAS even with `avx and fma` flags (but not Intel MKL). The command used to compile with OpenBLAS is:
```bash
g++ -o /home/[user]/libsystemml.so systemml-cpp/systemml.cpp  -I/usr/lib/jvm/java-1.8.0-openjdk-1.8.0.111-1.b15.el7_2.x86_64/include -Isystemml-cpp -I/opt/openblas/include -I/usr/lib/jvm/java-1.8.0-openjdk-1.8.0.111-1.b15.el7_2.x86_64/include/linux -lopenblas -lpthread -lm -ldl -DUSE_OPEN_BLAS -L/opt/openblas/lib -fopenmp -O3 -shared -fPIC -mavx -mfma
```

@fschueler Either I am not compiling [openblas in an optimal manner](https://github.com/niketanpansare/incubator-systemml/blob/for_cpp/src/main/cpp/README.md#option-2-install-openblas) (i.e. AVX/SSE2/FMA are not getting turned on by default) or your previous experiments might be using OpenCL?

@mboehm7  Please see below the graphs comparing speedup with Intel MKL and  OpenBLAS respectively. As per your suggestion, I have marked the cases where multi-threading was not enabled 

@fschueler  I think we donot see the speedup in OpenBLAS because it is likely not being compiled with AVX.

![dec18_mkl](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11686380/21318354/b9320c06-c5bd-11e6-9440-73e285b18f97.png)
![dec18_openblas](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11686380/21318361/bd76b55a-c5bd-11e6-9542-5c52cf36b613.png)

The R script used to generate above graphs:
```python
t = read.csv("time1.txt", header=TRUE)
t = subset(t, BLAS != "IntelMKL" & Time > 0)
temp = subset(t, BLAS == "Java")
for(i in 1:nrow(temp)) {
  M1 = temp[i,]$M
  N2 = temp[i,]$N
  K1 = temp[i,]$K
  temp[i,]$Time = subset(t, BLAS == "Java" & M == M1 & N == N2 & K == K1)$Time /  subset(t, BLAS != "Java" & M == M1 & N == N2 & K == K1)$Time
}
qplot(N, Time, data=temp, color=IsSingleThreaded, facets=M~K, xlab="Common dimension (N)", ylab="Speedup", main="Matrix multiplication (Speedup = CP/OpenBLAS)")
```

@nakul02 @fschueler @dusenberrymw Can you help me with Mac command for OpenBLAS and Intel MKL ? https://github.com/niketanpansare/incubator-systemml/blob/for_cpp/src/main/python/setup.py#L70

@fschueler I used following steps to compile OpenBLAS:
```bash
git clone https://github.com/xianyi/OpenBLAS
cd OpenBLAS
make FC=gfortran
sudo make PREFIX=/opt/openblas install
```

Also, the output of `getarch` utility included in OpenBLAS directory is as follows:
```bash
$ ./getarch 0

```

It is important to maintain consistency in our APIs across the different languages.

This algorithm is supposed to work fine. But there is one weird issue. In line 54, I am defining `Q = eye[,1:n]`. So it is supposed to be a `m x n` matrix (the same size as the `H` matrix). In the first iteration it is `m x n`, but in the successive iterations, `Q` becomes `m x m`. And because of this the algorithm breaks down. This is definitely a bug. Any suggestions/fixes/workarounds? @nakul02 @niketanpansare @mboehm7

@iyounus - are you running this in spark mode or standalone?
I can get it run on standalone. I needed to change how "k" is accessed in the function "QR_recursive". I needed to pass it in as a parameter.

[Here](https://gist.github.com/nakul02/651a139d53b929d08355fb447c489caf) is the script I ran.

(I named it .R for the syntax highlighting, but it is a DML file)
LGTM. Thank you @nakul02

I'm running it in standalone, no spark at this time.
There was a mistake in the algorithm. I didn't have this problem in my test code. I've fixed the script. Here is how you can reproduce the problem. Try running the script like this (in dml):
```
X = rand(rows=15, cols=10)
print(toString(X))
[Q, R] = QR_recursive(X, 3)

A = Q %*% R
print(toString(A))
```
`X` and `A` should be identical.
If the number of columns in your input matrix is less than k (now I called it q in new script), then there is no recursion and you go directly to base case. In that case there is not problem.

Ok, so with this I am able to reproduce the error.
There is something wrong with the optimizer. When I set optimization level to 0, the problem doesn't occur.
To set the optimization level to 0, set the appropriate property in the `SystemML-config.xml` file.
If you are running systemml from the `bin/systemml` script, just change the `conf/SystemML-config.xml` file.
@iyounus, you might want to open a JIRA about this.

I have got this PR to functionally complete state. Here are the features that are included as part of this PR:

1. Automatic detection of BLAS and GPU as well as including the correct dependency. Please see http://niketanpansare.github.io/incubator-systemml/accelerator for usage.
  * By default, if the user invokes SystemML via commandline or scala shell, everything works as our existing setup. Only when user provides `systemml-accelerator.jar` does GPU and BLAS potentially get enabled. 
  * No additional steps of including JCuda java and lib required.
  * This setup will work in hybrid cluster environment (with/without gpus, different blas) as well.
  * We support GPU on Linux (x86_64 and powerpc), Mac (x86_64), Windows (x86_64) and BLAS on Linux (x86_64), Mac (x86_64), Windows (x86_64). For other setups, we revert back to LibMatrixMult and non-GPU backend.

2. Support BLAS for matrix multiplication, conv2d and conv2d_backward_data.

3. Performance comparison of LibMatrixMult with MKL and OpenBLAS.

@nakul02 @mboehm7 @bertholdreinwald @dusenberrymw @deroneriksson @asurve @gweidner @fschueler   Can you **please** try the following script in your environment and comment back on this PR with the log lines prefixed by `INFO accelerator`. This should help us identify the setup on which this PR is tested. 

```bash
git clone https://github.com/niketanpansare/incubator-systemml.git
cd incubator-systemml
git checkout for_cpp
mvn clean package -P distribution
pip install target/systemml-0.12.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT-python.tgz
pyspark
>>> from systemml import random
>>> m1 = random.uniform(size=(1000,1000))
>>> m2 = random.uniform(size=(1000,1000))
>>> m3 = m1.dot(m2).toNumPy()
```

@nakul02 Can we please close this PR and use https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/307 instead ?
but let's keep native BLAS and GPU backend separate.

Can we please move this discussion to https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/307 ? The PR addresses:

1. the deployment related issue for BLAS as well as **JCuda**. It also allows users to selectively turn-off BLAS as well as JCuda and always defaults to Java library. Also, it handles heterogeneity of the cluster and is one of the required step to make progress for distributed GPU backend.
2. avoids the need for `-gpu` flag and provides a common interface irrespective of the programmatic APIs such as MLContext, DSL, mllearn, etc
All tests passed [here](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/966/).
LGTM. I will merge.

@nakul02 just a side comment on naming conventions: the opcode uark+ stands for unary aggregate row kahan plus. Could you please either rename this operation to uar+ or (consistently with the other backends) implement the kahan summation?

@mboehm7 - Thanks, I've updated rerouting calls of `uark+`, `uar+` to the GPU summation reduction implementation (when applicable).
For the time being, we are redirecting kahan sum reductions to regular summation reduction implementations on the GPU. This is documented [here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/runtime/matrix/data/LibMatrixCUDA.java#L928).

This can be tested with:
```
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext.ScriptFactory._
val ml = new MLContext(sc)
val habermanUrl = "http://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/machine-learning-databases/haberman/haberman.data"
val typesRDD = sc.parallelize(Array("1.0,1.0,1.0,2.0"))
val scriptUrl = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/apache/incubator-systemml/master/scripts/algorithms/Univar-Stats.dml"
val uni = dmlFromUrl(scriptUrl).in("A", new java.net.URL(habermanUrl)).in("K", typesRDD).in("$CONSOLE_OUTPUT", true)
ml.execute(uni)
val se = uni.getScriptExecutor
val program = se.getDmlProgram
```

My line of thinking was this: convolution-related operator implies "tensors" and since almost all the frameworks represents tensors in dense format, I thought of proposing this PR. For example: CuDNN only supports dense tensors. Anyways, let's exhaust approaches such as https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/329 and then consider this PR :)

"relu-maxpooling fusion" especially makes sense becomes relu becomes a no-op. We can definitely consider "conv-relu-conv" pattern and "relu-dropout" pattern. It is important to note that we **support sparse operators** for most of these cases including sparse matrix multiplication. However, there is a tradeoff in the runtime performance of sparse operators v/s memory consumption (i.e. cusparse matrix multiplication with sparsity 0.4 will be slower than cublas matrix multiplication, assuming no conversion). Based on previous machine learning workloads, we decided to keep threshold of conversion 0.4, and that threshold is respected throughout the system (i.e. via examine sparsity). I see only three possible solutions that respect this design:
1. Operator fusion (where temporary data is not converted to sparse). For example: this PR
2. Reduce the threshold globally. For example: https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/320
3. Code generation.
That makes sense. I will look into runtime fused operators for such patterns.

Yeah I completely agree that dense makes more sense particularly for the mini-batch cases, and especially for those involving GPU.  I'm just curious if the sparse format could still be useful for full-batch, distributed, non-GPU prediction cases.  Once we have a distributed implementation of convolution and max pooling it will be an interesting experiment. :)

In the meantime, I'm not opposed to going ahead and making use of this.  As long as we keep the change simple, we can always come back and reevaluate it for the case above.

As I already commented on a previous PR, I'm completely against these flags to disable sparse matrices and caching. From my perspective, it only works around underlying issues that should be addressed at runtime level.

For example, for unary operations like relu, we could scan the input twice in order to determine the exact nnz of the output, and thus the correct sparse/dense format, before allocation. Having the nnz per row would also replace the log M allocations per row with a single allocation. Due to copy-on-write the sparse intermediate would then anyway not be updated, except for in-place indexing. Note that we do similar things for sparse matrix transpose as well.

Furthermore, there is also a technical issue. Having the static flag would affect all operations in a session; coming through MLContext, even across scripts.

Results of experiments: The improvement with sgd_nesterov updates was only 1.07x (less that what I had expected). The average time per call for update_nesterov is comparable to that of +\*, even though it performs an additional multiplication and +\*. 

For now, I will keep the udf, but revert back sgd_nesterov to previous implementation and explore other improvements.
LGTM. I will merge. Thanks @nakul02

I think that given the newer & expanded range of ML workloads that are now being run on SystemML, we should go back through the system and challenge previous assumptions that were made, such as the sparsity threshold.  We've already started this by breaking previous assumptions of tall-skinny matrices, for example.  A big issue we're seeing now is models that contain several computational transformations ("layers") rather than just a couple.

Let's pause on (1) & (3) for a bit, and focus on (2) and a more general approach of reevaluating previous assumptions in the system.  Sparse support, caching, and native BLAS come to mind immediately.
[SYSTEMML-1140](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-1140) would be a good place to start.
@niketanpansare I have transferred our conversation regarding which of the steps to move forward with on [SYSTEMML-686](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-686).

I think it is time to merge this PR into the master.  Thoughts?

@niketanpansare W.r.t. BLAS on OS X / macOS, currently, the preferred and default BLAS implementation is [Apple Accelerate](https://developer.apple.com/reference/accelerate).  Like C-BLAS, Atlas, OpenBLAS, Intel MKL, etc, Accelerate implements the BLAS API, and in terms of performance, Accelerate is generally the fastest BLAS implementation on OS X / macOS. Also, just to be clear, Accelerate is part of OS X / macOS, and does not require any installation.

For example, a `pip install numpy` on OS X / macOS will result in NumPy automatically linked to Accelerate:

```python
import numpy as np
np.__config__.show()
```
```
blas_mkl_info:
  NOT AVAILABLE
openblas_info:
  NOT AVAILABLE
atlas_3_10_blas_threads_info:
  NOT AVAILABLE
atlas_3_10_blas_info:
  NOT AVAILABLE
atlas_blas_threads_info:
  NOT AVAILABLE
atlas_blas_info:
  NOT AVAILABLE
blas_opt_info:
    extra_compile_args = ['-msse3', '-I/System/Library/Frameworks/vecLib.framework/Headers']
    extra_link_args = ['-Wl,-framework', '-Wl,Accelerate']
    define_macros = [('NO_ATLAS_INFO', 3), ('HAVE_CBLAS', None)]

As for the rest of this PR, the `systemml-accelerator.jar` idea is awesome, but I don't think we will be able to ship a release that contains that JAR due to all of the [binary files included](https://github.com/niketanpansare/systemml-accelerator/tree/master/src/main/resources/lib). cc @lresende, @deroneriksson

Thanks @dusenberrymw  ....  We have three options:

1. Seperate project option: We have a seperate project https://github.com/niketanpansare/systemml-accelerator and
- Provided dependency:   We host `systemml-accelerator.jar` on maven central once this PR is accepted and provide the link in the documentation. I can also create a pip installer for that.
- Compile dependency: Here we include a fat artifact where we compile `systemml-accelerator.jar`  into SystemML. Thereby, no requiring an release of systemml-accelerator.jar.

2. One project option: We include the files from https://github.com/niketanpansare/systemml-accelerator into our project and have a separate profile to compile libraries conditionally.
Thanks @nakul02 ... nice catch. I will merge :)

Updated the PR to support generic p values. This allows us to continue making progress in optimizing MNIST demo and when https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-515 is resolved, we can update dropout too.
Forgot to handle an if case, will update the PR soon :)

@niketanpansare I'm still not a fan of this update.  I think it's great to explore areas of improvement, but optimizing only for single, specific usages (i.e. only for `p=0.5`) is why SystemML is in its current, fragile state.  I.e. `dropout` needs to have the same level of performance for all levels of `p`,  rather than exhibit great performance properties *only* for specific values of `p`.  For more concrete evidence, that demo will involve a hyperparameter search over `p`, rather than always selecting `p=0.5`.

-1 for the temporary patch.  Let's just fix `rand` and fix the issue entirely.

Ok, I will close this PR for now. Once https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-515 is resolved, please use `mask = rand(rows=nrow(X), cols=ncol(X), min=1, max=1, sparsity=p)` rather than `mask = rand(rows=nrow(X), cols=ncol(X), min=0, max=1) <= p` as the former has much better performance.

Can test with:
```
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext.ScriptFactory._
val ml = new MLContext(sc)
val str = """
A = matrix("1 2 3 4 5 6", rows=3, cols=2)
for(i in 1:nrow(A)) {
    print("for A[" + i + ",1]:" + as.scalar(A[i,1]))
}
"""
val scr = dml(str)
ml.execute(scr)
scr.getScriptExecutor.getDmlProgram
```
